sections.title: Description of
sections.snippet:
Take a look at video.

<iframe width="420" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/p_pvslS4gEI" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Mob coding is many people working on the same problem, on the same computer, when one person codes and the rest discuss/chat the solution. Kind of XP/pair programming.

sections.title: Likes
sections.snippet:
* Knowledge transfer
 * Communication
 * Instant code review
 * Less paperwork/jirawork
 
Many of us liked learning how to do new things by watching others. From details like keyboard shortcuts to more conceptual things like how to plan a piece of code.

sections.title: Dislikes
sections.snippet:
* Formatting and some details can take a long time
 * Sometimes commenting can interrupt coding
 * things fall apart without an agenda
 * Resolving disparate coding styles

sections.title: Lessons Learned
sections.snippet:
* For us writing about code seemed to work better than writing actual code.
 * If the workflow is not completely ironed out, then it is easy to spend a lot of time on things like figuring out how to do certain things
